content: Analyze decisions and strategies using probability concepts (e.g., product testing, medical testing, pulling a hockey goalie at the end of a game).
meta: Use probability to evaluate outcomes of decisions
Higher Mathematics Course — Statistics and Probability<sup>★</sup>

content: Use probabilities to make fair decisions (e.g., drawing by lots, using a random number generator).
meta: Use probability to evaluate outcomes of decisions
Higher Mathematics Course — Statistics and Probability<sup>★</sup>

content: Weigh the possible outcomes of a decision by assigning probabilities to payoff values and finding expected values.
meta: Use probability to evaluate outcomes of decisions
Higher Mathematics Course — Statistics and Probability<sup>★</sup>

content: Develop a probability distribution for a random variable defined for a sample space in which probabilities are assigned empirically; find the expected value.
meta: Calculate expected values and use them to solve problems
Higher Mathematics Course — Statistics and Probability<sup>★</sup>

content: Develop a probability distribution for a random variable defined for a sample space in which theoretical probabilities can be calculated; find the expected value.
meta: Calculate expected values and use them to solve problems
Higher Mathematics Course — Statistics and Probability<sup>★</sup>

content: Calculate the expected value of a random variable; interpret it as the mean of the probability distribution.
meta: Calculate expected values and use them to solve problems
Higher Mathematics Course — Statistics and Probability<sup>★</sup>

content: Define a random variable for a quantity of interest by assigning a numerical value to each event in a sample space; graph the corresponding probability distribution using the same graphical displays as for data distributions.
meta: Calculate expected values and use them to solve problems
Higher Mathematics Course — Statistics and Probability<sup>★</sup>

content: Use permutations and combinations to compute probabilities of compound events and solve problems.
meta: Use the rules of probability to compute probabilities of compound events in a uniform probability model
Conditional Probability and the Rules of Probability
Higher Mathematics Course — Statistics and Probability<sup>★</sup>

content: Apply the general Multiplication Rule in a uniform probability model, P(A and B) = P(A)P(B|A) = P(B)P(A|B), and interpret the answer in terms of the model.
meta: Use the rules of probability to compute probabilities of compound events in a uniform probability model
Conditional Probability and the Rules of Probability
Higher Mathematics Course — Statistics and Probability<sup>★</sup>

content: Apply the Addition Rule, P(A or B) = P(A) + P(B) - P(A and B), and interpret the answer in terms of the model.
meta: Use the rules of probability to compute probabilities of compound events in a uniform probability model
Conditional Probability and the Rules of Probability
Higher Mathematics Course — Statistics and Probability<sup>★</sup>

content: Find the conditional probability of A given B as the fraction of B's outcomes that also belong to A, and interpret the answer in terms of the model.
meta: Use the rules of probability to compute probabilities of compound events in a uniform probability model
Conditional Probability and the Rules of Probability
Higher Mathematics Course — Statistics and Probability<sup>★</sup>

content: Recognize and explain the concepts of conditional probability and independence in everyday language and everyday situations.
meta: Understand independence and conditional probability and use them to interpret data
Conditional Probability and the Rules of Probability
Higher Mathematics Course — Statistics and Probability<sup>★</sup>

content: Construct and interpret two-way frequency tables of data when two categories are associated with each object being classified. Use the two-way table as a sample space to decide if events are independent and to approximate conditional probabilities.
meta: Understand independence and conditional probability and use them to interpret data
Conditional Probability and the Rules of Probability
Higher Mathematics Course — Statistics and Probability<sup>★</sup>

content: Understand the conditional probability of A given B as P(A and B)/P(B), and interpret independence of A and B as saying that the conditional probability of A given B is the same as the probability of A, and the conditional probability of B given A is the same as the probability of B.
meta: Understand independence and conditional probability and use them to interpret data
Conditional Probability and the Rules of Probability
Higher Mathematics Course — Statistics and Probability<sup>★</sup>

content: Understand that two events A and B are independent if the probability of A and B occurring together is the product of their probabilities, and use this characterization to determine if they are independent.
meta: Understand independence and conditional probability and use them to interpret data
Conditional Probability and the Rules of Probability
Higher Mathematics Course — Statistics and Probability<sup>★</sup>

content: Describe events as subsets of a sample space (the set of outcomes) using characteristics (or categories) of the outcomes, or as unions, intersections, or complements of other events ("or," "and," "not").
meta: Understand independence and conditional probability and use them to interpret data
Conditional Probability and the Rules of Probability
Higher Mathematics Course — Statistics and Probability<sup>★</sup>

content: Evaluate reports based on data.
meta: Make inferences and justify conclusions from sample surveys, experiments, and observational studies
Higher Mathematics Course — Statistics and Probability<sup>★</sup>

content: Use data from a randomized experiment to compare two treatments; use simulations to decide if differences between parameters are significant.
meta: Make inferences and justify conclusions from sample surveys, experiments, and observational studies
Higher Mathematics Course — Statistics and Probability<sup>★</sup>

content: Use data from a sample survey to estimate a population mean or proportion; develop a margin of error through the use of simulation models for random sampling.
meta: Make inferences and justify conclusions from sample surveys, experiments, and observational studies
Higher Mathematics Course — Statistics and Probability<sup>★</sup>

content: Recognize the purposes of and differences among sample surveys, experiments, and observational studies; explain how randomization relates to each.
meta: Make inferences and justify conclusions from sample surveys, experiments, and observational studies
Higher Mathematics Course — Statistics and Probability<sup>★</sup>

content: Decide if a specified model is consistent with results from a given data-generating process, e.g., using simulation.
meta: Understand and evaluate random processes underlying statistical experiments
Higher Mathematics Course — Statistics and Probability<sup>★</sup>

content: Understand statistics as a process for making inferences about population parameters based on a random sample from that population.
meta: Understand and evaluate random processes underlying statistical experiments
Higher Mathematics Course — Statistics and Probability<sup>★</sup>

content: Distinguish between correlation and causation.
meta: Higher Mathematics Course — Statistics and Probability<sup>★</sup>

content: Compute (using technology) and interpret the correlation coefficient of a linear fit.
meta: Higher Mathematics Course — Statistics and Probability<sup>★</sup>

content: Interpret the slope (rate of change) and the intercept (constant term) of a linear model in the context of the data.
meta: Higher Mathematics Course — Statistics and Probability<sup>★</sup>

content: Represent data on two quantitative variables on a scatter plot, and describe how the variables are related.
meta: Summarize, represent, and interpret data on two categorical and quantitative variables
Higher Mathematics Course — Statistics and Probability<sup>★</sup>

content: Summarize categorical data for two categories in two-way frequency tables. Interpret relative frequencies in the context of the data (including joint, marginal, and conditional relative frequencies). Recognize possible associations and trends in the data.
meta: Summarize, represent, and interpret data on two categorical and quantitative variables
Higher Mathematics Course — Statistics and Probability<sup>★</sup>

content: Use the mean and standard deviation of a data set to fit it to a normal distribution and to estimate population percentages. Recognize that there are data sets for which such a procedure is not appropriate. Use calculators, spreadsheets, and tables to estimate areas under the normal curve.
meta: Summarize, represent, and interpret data on a single count or measurement variable
Higher Mathematics Course — Statistics and Probability<sup>★</sup>

content: Interpret differences in shape, center, and spread in the context of the data sets, accounting for possible effects of extreme data points (outliers).
meta: Summarize, represent, and interpret data on a single count or measurement variable
Higher Mathematics Course — Statistics and Probability<sup>★</sup>

content: Use statistics appropriate to the shape of the data distribution to compare center (median, mean) and spread (interquartile range, standard deviation) of two or more different data sets.
meta: Summarize, represent, and interpret data on a single count or measurement variable
Higher Mathematics Course — Statistics and Probability<sup>★</sup>

content: Represent data with plots on the real number line (dot plots, histograms, and box plots).
meta: Summarize, represent, and interpret data on a single count or measurement variable
Higher Mathematics Course — Statistics and Probability<sup>★</sup>

content: Apply geometric methods to solve design problems (e.g., designing an object or structure to satisfy physical constraints or minimize cost; working with typographic grid systems based on ratios).<sup>★</sup>
meta: Apply geometric concepts in modeling situations

content: Apply concepts of density based on area and volume in modeling situations (e.g., persons per square mile, BTUs per cubic foot).<sup>★</sup>
meta: Apply geometric concepts in modeling situations

content: Use geometric shapes, their measures, and their properties to describe objects (e.g., modeling a tree trunk or a human torso as a cylinder).<sup>★</sup>
meta: Apply geometric concepts in modeling situations

content: Verify experimentally that in a triangle, angles opposite longer sides are larger, sides opposite larger angles are longer, and the sum of any two side lengths is greater than the remaining side length; apply these relationships to solve real-world and mathematical problems.
meta: Visualize relationships between two-dimensional and three-dimensional objects

content: Know that the effect of a scale factor k greater than zero on length, area, and volume is to multiply each by k, k², and k³, respectively; determine length, area and volume measures using scale factors.
meta: Visualize relationships between two-dimensional and three-dimensional objects

content: Identify the shapes of two-dimensional cross-sections of three-dimensional objects, and identify three-dimensional objects generated by rotations of two-dimensional objects.
meta: Visualize relationships between two-dimensional and three-dimensional objects

content: Use volume formulas for cylinders, pyramids, cones, and spheres to solve problems.<sup>★</sup>
meta: Explain volume formulas and use them to solve problems

content: Give an informal argument using Cavalieri's principle for the formulas for the volume of a sphere and other solid figures.
meta: Explain volume formulas and use them to solve problems

content: Give an informal argument for the formulas for the circumference of a circle, area of a circle, volume of a cylinder, pyramid, and cone.
meta: Explain volume formulas and use them to solve problems

content: Use coordinates to compute perimeters of polygons and areas of triangles and rectangles, e.g., using the distance formula.<sup>★</sup>
meta: Use coordinates to prove simple geometric theorems algebraically

content: Find the point on a directed line segment between two given points that partitions the segment in a given ratio.
meta: Use coordinates to prove simple geometric theorems algebraically

content: Prove the slope criteria for parallel and perpendicular lines and use them to solve geometric problems (e.g., find the equation of a line parallel or perpendicular to a given line that passes through a given point).
meta: Use coordinates to prove simple geometric theorems algebraically

content: Use coordinates to prove simple geometric theorems algebraically.
meta: Use coordinates to prove simple geometric theorems algebraically

content: Given a quadratic equation of the form ax² + by² + cx + dy + e = 0, use the method for completing the square to put the equation into standard form; identify whether the graph of the equation is a circle, ellipse, parabola, or hyperbola and graph the equation.
meta: Translate between the geometric description and the equation for a conic section

content: Derive the equations of ellipses and hyperbolas given the foci, using the fact that the sum or difference of distances from the foci is constant.
meta: Translate between the geometric description and the equation for a conic section

content: Derive the equation of a parabola given a focus and directrix.
meta: Translate between the geometric description and the equation for a conic section

content: Derive the equation of a circle of given center and radius using the Pythagorean Theorem; complete the square to find the center and radius of a circle given by an equation.
meta: Translate between the geometric description and the equation for a conic section

content: Derive using similarity the fact that the length of the arc intercepted by an angle is proportional to the radius, and define the radian measure of the angle as the constant of proportionality; derive the formula for the area of a sector. Convert between degrees and radians.
meta: Find arc lengths and areas of sectors of circles

content: Construct a tangent line from a point outside a given circle to the circle.
meta: Understand and apply theorems about circles

content: Construct the inscribed and circumscribed circles of a triangle, and prove properties of angles for a quadrilateral inscribed in a circle.
meta: Understand and apply theorems about circles

content: Identify and describe relationships among inscribed angles, radii, and chords.
meta: Understand and apply theorems about circles

content: Prove that all circles are similar.
meta: Understand and apply theorems about circles

content: Understand and apply the Law of Sines and the Law of Cosines to find unknown measurements in right and non-right triangles (e.g., surveying problems, resultant forces).
Prove the Laws of Sines and Cosines and use them to solve problems.
Derive the formula A = 1/2 ab sin(C) for the area of a triangle by drawing an auxiliary line from a vertex perpendicular to the opposite side.
Derive and use the trigonometric ratios for special right triangles (30°, 60°, 90°and 45°, 45°, 90°)
meta: Define trigonometric ratios and solve problems involving right triangles

content: Use trigonometric ratios and the Pythagorean Theorem to solve right triangles in applied problems.<sup>★</sup>
meta: Define trigonometric ratios and solve problems involving right triangles

content: Explain and use the relationship between the sine and cosine of complementary angles.
meta: Define trigonometric ratios and solve problems involving right triangles

content: Understand that by similarity, side ratios in right triangles are properties of the angles in the triangle, leading to definitions of trigonometric ratios for acute angles.
meta: Define trigonometric ratios and solve problems involving right triangles

content: Use congruence and similarity criteria for triangles to solve problems and to prove relationships in geometric figures.
Prove theorems about triangles.
Use the properties of similarity transformations to establish the AA criterion for two triangles to be similar.
meta: Understand similarity in terms of similarity transformations

content: Given two figures, use the definition of similarity in terms of similarity transformations to decide if they are similar; explain using similarity transformations the meaning of similarity for triangles as the equality of all corresponding pairs of angles and the proportionality of all corresponding pairs of sides.
meta: Understand similarity in terms of similarity transformations

content: Verify experimentally the properties of dilations given by a center and a scale factor:
meta: Understand similarity in terms of similarity transformations

content: Construct an equilateral triangle, a square, and a regular hexagon inscribed in a circle.

Make formal geometric constructions with a variety of tools and methods (compass and straightedge, string, reflective devices, paper folding, dynamic geometric software, etc.). Copying a segment; copying an angle; bisecting a segment; bisecting an angle; constructing perpendicular lines, including the perpendicular bisector of a line segment; and constructing a line parallel to a given line through a point not on the line.
Prove theorems about parallelograms.
Prove theorems about triangles.
Prove theorems about lines and angles.
Explain how the criteria for triangle congruence (ASA, SAS, and SSS) follow from the definition of congruence in terms of rigid motions.
meta: Understand congruence in terms of rigid motions

content: Use the definition of congruence in terms of rigid motions to show that two triangles are congruent if and only if corresponding pairs of sides and corresponding pairs of angles are congruent.
meta: Understand congruence in terms of rigid motions

content: Use geometric descriptions of rigid motions to transform figures and to predict the effect of a given rigid motion on a given figure; given two figures, use the definition of congruence in terms of rigid motions to decide if they are congruent.
meta: Understand congruence in terms of rigid motions

content: Given a geometric figure and a rotation, reflection, or translation, draw the transformed figure using, e.g., graph paper, tracing paper, or geometry software. Specify a sequence of transformations that will carry a given figure onto another.
meta: Experiment with transformations in the plane

content: Develop definitions of rotations, reflections, and translations in terms of angles, circles, perpendicular lines, parallel lines, and line segments.
meta: Experiment with transformations in the plane

content: Given a rectangle, parallelogram, trapezoid, or regular polygon, describe the rotations and reflections that carry it onto itself.
meta: Experiment with transformations in the plane

content: Represent transformations in the plane using, e.g., transparencies and geometry software; describe transformations as functions that take points in the plane as inputs and give other points as outputs. Compare transformations that preserve distance and angle to those that do not (e.g., translation versus horizontal stretch).
meta: Experiment with transformations in the plane

content: Know precise definitions of angle, circle, perpendicular line, parallel line, and line segment, based on the undefined notions of point, line, distance along a line, and distance around a circular arc.
meta: Experiment with transformations in the plane

content: Prove the half angle and double angle identities for sine and cosine and use them to solve problems.
Prove the addition and subtraction formulas for sine, cosine, and tangent and use them to solve problems.
Prove the Pythagorean identity sin²(θ) + cos²(θ) = 1 and use it to find sin(θ), cos(θ), or tan(θ) given sin(θ), cos(θ), or tan(θ) and the quadrant of the angle.
Use inverse functions to solve trigonometric equations that arise in modeling contexts; evaluate the solutions using technology, and interpret them in terms of the context.<sup>★</sup>
meta: Model periodic phenomena with trigonometric functions

content: Understand that restricting a trigonometric function to a domain on which it is always increasing or always decreasing allows its inverse to be constructed.
meta: Model periodic phenomena with trigonometric functions

content: Choose trigonometric functions to model periodic phenomena with specified amplitude, frequency, and midline.<sup>★</sup>
meta: Model periodic phenomena with trigonometric functions

content: Use the unit circle to explain symmetry (odd and even) and periodicity of trigonometric functions.
meta: Extend the domain of trigonometric functions using the unit circle

content: Use special triangles to determine geometrically the values of sine, cosine, tangent for π/3, π/4 and π/6, and use the unit circle to express the values of sine, cosine, and tangent for π-x, π+x, and 2π-x in terms of their values for x, where x is any real number.
meta: Extend the domain of trigonometric functions using the unit circle

content: Graph all 6 basic trigonometric functions.
meta: Extend the domain of trigonometric functions using the unit circle

content: Explain how the unit circle in the coordinate plane enables the extension of trigonometric functions to all real numbers, interpreted as radian measures of angles traversed counterclockwise around the unit circle.
meta: Extend the domain of trigonometric functions using the unit circle

content: Understand radian measure of an angle as the length of the arc on the unit circle subtended by the angle.
meta: Extend the domain of trigonometric functions using the unit circle

content: Apply quadratic functions to physical problems, such as the motion of an object under the force of gravity.
meta: Interpret expressions for functions in terms of the situation they model

content: Interpret the parameters in a linear or exponential function in terms of a context.
meta: Interpret expressions for functions in terms of the situation they model

content: Understand and use the properties of logarithms to simplify logarithmic numeric expressions and to identify their approximate values.
meta: Construct and compare linear, quadratic, and exponential models and solve problems

content: Use the definition of logarithms to translate between logarithms in any base.
meta: Construct and compare linear, quadratic, and exponential models and solve problems

content: Prove simple laws of logarithms.
meta: Construct and compare linear, quadratic, and exponential models and solve problems

content: For exponential models, express as a logarithm the solution to ab<sup>ct</sup> = d where a, c, and d are numbers and the base b is 2, 10, or e; evaluate the logarithm using technology.
meta: Construct and compare linear, quadratic, and exponential models and solve problems

content: Observe using graphs and tables that a quantity increasing exponentially eventually exceeds a quantity increasing linearly, quadratically, or (more generally) as a polynomial function.
meta: Construct and compare linear, quadratic, and exponential models and solve problems

content: Construct linear and exponential functions, including arithmetic and geometric sequences, given a graph, a description of a relationship, or two input-output pairs (include reading these from a table).
meta: Construct and compare linear, quadratic, and exponential models and solve problems

content: Distinguish between situations that can be modeled with linear functions and with exponential functions.
meta: Construct and compare linear, quadratic, and exponential models and solve problems

content: Understand the inverse relationship between exponents and logarithms and use this relationship to solve problems involving logarithms and exponents.
meta: Build new functions from existing functions

content: Find inverse functions.
meta: Build new functions from existing functions

content: Identify the effect on the graph of replacing f(x) by f(x) + k, k f(x), f(kx), and f(x + k) for specific values of k (both positive and negative); find the value of k given the graphs. Experiment with cases and illustrate an explanation of the effects on the graph using technology. Include recognizing even and odd functions from their graphs and algebraic expressions for them.
meta: Build new functions from existing functions

content: Write arithmetic and geometric sequences both recursively and with an explicit formula, use them to model situations, and translate between the two forms.<sup>★</sup>
meta: Build a function that models a relationship between two quantities

content: Write a function that describes a relationship between two quantities <sup>★</sup>
meta: Build a function that models a relationship between two quantities

content: Graph polar coordinates and curves. Convert between polar and rectangular coordinate systems.
Demonstrate an understanding of functions and equations defined parametrically and graph them.
Compare properties of two functions each represented in a different way (algebraically, graphically, numerically in tables, or by verbal descriptions).
Write a function defined by an expression in different but equivalent forms to reveal and explain different properties of the function.
Graph functions expressed symbolically and show key features of the graph, by hand in simple cases and using technology for more complicated cases.<sup>★</sup>
Calculate and interpret the average rate of change of a function (presented symbolically or as a table) over a specified interval. Estimate the rate of change from a graph.<sup>★</sup>
meta: Interpret functions that arise in applications in terms of the context

content: Relate the domain of a function to its graph and, where applicable, to the quantitative relationship it describes.<sup>★</sup>
meta: Interpret functions that arise in applications in terms of the context

content: For a function that models a relationship between two quantities, interpret key features of graphs and tables in terms of the quantities, and sketch graphs showing key features given a verbal description of the relationship.<sup>★</sup>
meta: Interpret functions that arise in applications in terms of the context

content: Recognize that sequences are functions, sometimes defined recursively, whose domain is a subset of the integers.
meta: Understand the concept of a function and use function notation

content: Use function notation, evaluate functions for inputs in their domains, and interpret statements that use function notation in terms of a context.
meta: Understand the concept of a function and use function notation

content: Understand that a function from one set (called the domain) to another set (called the range) assigns to each element of the domain exactly one element of the range. If f is a function and x is an element of its domain, then f(x) denotes the output of f corresponding to the input x. The graph of f is the graph of the equation y = f(x).
meta: Understand the concept of a function and use function notation

content: Graph the solutions to a linear inequality in two variables as a half-plane (excluding the boundary in the case of a strict inequality), and graph the solution set to a system of linear inequalities in two variables as the intersection of the corresponding half-planes.
meta: Represent and solve equations and inequalities graphically

content: Explain why the x-coordinates of the points where the graphs of the equations y = f(x) and y = g(x) intersect are the solutions of the equation f(x) = g(x); find the solutions approximately, e.g., using technology to graph the functions, make tables of values, or find successive approximations. Include cases where f(x) and/or g(x) are linear, polynomial, rational, absolute value, exponential, and logarithmic functions.<sup>★</sup>
meta: Represent and solve equations and inequalities graphically

content: Understand that the graph of an equation in two variables is the set of all its solutions plotted in the coordinate plane, often forming a curve (which could be a line).
meta: Represent and solve equations and inequalities graphically

content: Find the inverse of a matrix if it exists and use it to solve systems of linear equations (using technology for matrices of dimension 3 × 3 or greater).
Represent a system of linear equations as a single matrix equation in a vector variable.
Solve a simple system consisting of a linear equation and a quadratic equation in two variables algebraically and graphically.
Solve systems of linear equations exactly and approximately (e.g., with graphs), focusing on pairs of linear equations in two variables.
Prove that, given a system of two equations in two variables, replacing one equation by the sum of that equation and a multiple of the other produces a system with the same solutions.
Solve quadratic equations in one variable.
meta: Solve equations and inequalities in one variable

content: Solve one-variable equations and inequalities involving absolute value, graphing the solutions and interpreting them in context.
meta: Solve equations and inequalities in one variable

content: Solve linear equations and inequalities in one variable, including equations with coefficients represented by letters.
meta: Solve equations and inequalities in one variable

content: Solve simple rational and radical equations in one variable, and give examples showing how extraneous solutions may arise.
meta: Understand solving equations as a process of reasoning and explain the reasoning

content: Explain each step in solving a simple equation as following from the equality of numbers asserted at the previous step, starting from the assumption that the original equation has a solution. Construct a viable argument to justify a solution method.
meta: Understand solving equations as a process of reasoning and explain the reasoning

content: Rearrange formulas to highlight a quantity of interest, using the same reasoning as in solving equations.
meta: Create equations that describe numbers or relationships

content: Represent constraints by equations or inequalities, and by systems of equations and/or inequalities, and interpret solutions as viable or nonviable options in a modeling context.
meta: Create equations that describe numbers or relationships

content: Create equations in two or more variables to represent relationships between quantities; graph equations on coordinate axes with labels and scales.
meta: Create equations that describe numbers or relationships

content: Create equations and inequalities in one variable including ones with absolute value and use them to solve problems. Include equations arising from linear and quadratic functions, and simple rational and exponential functions.
meta: Create equations that describe numbers or relationships

content: Understand that rational expressions form a system analogous to the rational numbers, closed under addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division by a nonzero rational expression; add, subtract, multiply, and divide rational expressions.
meta: Arithmetic with Polynomials and Rational Expressions

content: Rewrite simple rational expressions in different forms; write <sup>a(x </sup>/<sub>b(x)</sub> in the form q(x) + <sup>r(x)</sup>/<sub>b(x)</sub>, where a(x), b(x), q(x), and r(x) are polynomials with the degree of r(x) less than the degree of b(x), using inspection, long division, or, for the more complicated examples, a computer algebra system.
meta: Arithmetic with Polynomials and Rational Expressions

content: Know and apply the Binomial Theorem for the expansion of (x + y)<sup>n</sup> in powers of x and y for a positive integer n, where x and y are any numbers, with coefficients determined for example by Pascal's Triangle.
meta: Use polynomial identities to solve problems
Arithmetic with Polynomials and Rational Expressions

content: Prove polynomial identities and use them to describe numerical relationships.
meta: Use polynomial identities to solve problems
Arithmetic with Polynomials and Rational Expressions

content: Identify zeros of polynomials when suitable factorizations are available, and use the zeros to construct a rough graph of the function defined by the polynomial.
meta: Understand the relationship between zeros and factors of polynomials
Arithmetic with Polynomials and Rational Expressions

content: Know and apply the Remainder Theorem: For a polynomial p(x) and a number a, the remainder on division by x - a is p(a), so p(a) = 0 if and only if (x - a) is a factor of p(x).
meta: Understand the relationship between zeros and factors of polynomials
Arithmetic with Polynomials and Rational Expressions

content: Understand that polynomials form a system analogous to the integers, namely, they are closed under the operations of addition, subtraction, and multiplication; add, subtract, and multiply polynomials.
meta: Arithmetic with Polynomials and Rational Expressions

content: Derive the formula for the sum of a finite geometric series (when the common ratio is not 1), and use the formula to solve problems.<sup>★</sup>
meta: Write expressions in equivalent forms to solve problems

content: Choose and produce an equivalent form of an expression to reveal and explain properties of the quantity represented by the expression.<sup>★</sup>
meta: Write expressions in equivalent forms to solve problems

content: Use the structure of an expression to identify ways to rewrite it.
Interpret expressions that represent a quantity in terms of its context <sup>★</sup>
Work with 2 × 2 matrices as transformations of the plane, and interpret the absolute value of the determinant in terms of area.
meta: Perform operations on matrices and use matrices in applications.
Higher Mathematics Course — Number and Quantity

content: Multiply a vector (regarded as a matrix with one column) by a matrix of suitable dimensions to produce another vector. Work with matrices as transformations of vectors.
meta: Perform operations on matrices and use matrices in applications.
Higher Mathematics Course — Number and Quantity

content: Understand that the zero and identity matrices play a role in matrix addition and multiplication similar to the role of 0 and 1 in the real numbers. The determinant of a square matrix is nonzero if and only if the matrix has a multiplicative inverse.
meta: Perform operations on matrices and use matrices in applications.
Higher Mathematics Course — Number and Quantity

content: Understand that, unlike multiplication of numbers, matrix multiplication for square matrices is not a commutative operation, but still satisfies the associative and distributive properties.
meta: Perform operations on matrices and use matrices in applications.
Higher Mathematics Course — Number and Quantity

content: Add, subtract, and multiply matrices of appropriate dimensions.
meta: Perform operations on matrices and use matrices in applications.
Higher Mathematics Course — Number and Quantity

content: Multiply matrices by scalars to produce new matrices, e.g., as when all of the payoffs in a game are doubled.
meta: Perform operations on matrices and use matrices in applications.
Higher Mathematics Course — Number and Quantity

content: Use matrices to represent and manipulate data, e.g., to represent payoffs or incidence relationships in a network.
meta: Perform operations on matrices and use matrices in applications.
Higher Mathematics Course — Number and Quantity

content: Multiply a vector by a scalar.
meta: Higher Mathematics Course — Number and Quantity

content: Add and subtract vectors.
meta: Higher Mathematics Course — Number and Quantity

content: Solve problems involving velocity and other quantities that can be represented by vectors.
meta: Represent and model with vector quantities.
Higher Mathematics Course — Number and Quantity

content: Find the components of a vector by subtracting the coordinates of an initial point from the coordinates of a terminal point.
meta: Represent and model with vector quantities.
Higher Mathematics Course — Number and Quantity

content: Recognize vector quantities as having both magnitude and direction. Represent vector quantities by directed line segments, and use appropriate symbols for vectors and their magnitudes (e.g., v, |v|, ||v||, v).
meta: Represent and model with vector quantities.
Higher Mathematics Course — Number and Quantity

content: Know the Fundamental Theorem of Algebra; show that it is true for quadratic polynomials.
meta: Use complex numbers in polynomial identities and equations.
Higher Mathematics Course — Number and Quantity

content: Extend polynomial identities to the complex numbers.
meta: Use complex numbers in polynomial identities and equations.
Higher Mathematics Course — Number and Quantity

content: Solve quadratic equations with real coefficients that have complex solutions.
meta: Use complex numbers in polynomial identities and equations.
Higher Mathematics Course — Number and Quantity

content: Calculate the distance between numbers in the complex plane as the modulus of the difference, and the midpoint of a segment as the average of the numbers at its endpoints.
meta: Represent complex numbers and their operations on the complex plane.
Higher Mathematics Course — Number and Quantity

content: Represent addition, subtraction, multiplication, and conjugation of complex numbers geometrically on the complex plane; use properties of this representation for computation.
meta: Represent complex numbers and their operations on the complex plane.
Higher Mathematics Course — Number and Quantity

content: Represent complex numbers on the complex plane in rectangular and polar form (including real and imaginary numbers), and explain why the rectangular and polar forms of a given complex number represent the same number.
meta: Represent complex numbers and their operations on the complex plane.
Higher Mathematics Course — Number and Quantity

content: Find the conjugate of a complex number; use conjugates to find moduli and quotients of complex numbers.
meta: Perform arithmetic operations with complex numbers.
Higher Mathematics Course — Number and Quantity

content: Use the relation i² = -1 and the commutative, associative, and distributive properties to add, subtract, and multiply complex numbers.
meta: Perform arithmetic operations with complex numbers.
Higher Mathematics Course — Number and Quantity

content: Know there is a complex number i such that i² = -1, and every complex number has the form a + bi with a and b real.
meta: Perform arithmetic operations with complex numbers.
Higher Mathematics Course — Number and Quantity

content: Choose a level of accuracy appropriate to limitations on measurement when reporting quantities.
meta: Reason quantitatively and use units to solve problems.
Higher Mathematics Course — Number and Quantity

content: Define appropriate quantities for the purpose of descriptive modeling.
meta: Reason quantitatively and use units to solve problems.
Higher Mathematics Course — Number and Quantity

content: Use units as a way to understand problems and to guide the solution of multi-step problems; choose and interpret units consistently in formulas; choose and interpret the scale and the origin in graphs and data displays.
meta: Reason quantitatively and use units to solve problems.
Higher Mathematics Course — Number and Quantity

content: Explain why the sum or product of two rational numbers is rational; that the sum of a rational number and an irrational number is irrational; and that the product of a nonzero rational number and an irrational number is irrational.
meta: Use properties of rational and irrational numbers.
Higher Mathematics Course — Number and Quantity

content: Rewrite expressions involving radicals and rational exponents using the properties of exponents.
meta: Extend the properties of exponents to rational exponents.
Higher Mathematics Course — Number and Quantity

content: Explain how the definition of the meaning of rational exponents follows from extending the properties of integer exponents to those values, allowing for a notation for radicals in terms of rational exponents.
meta: Extend the properties of exponents to rational exponents.
Higher Mathematics Course — Number and Quantity

content: Evaluate and compare strategies on the basis of expected values.
meta: (+) Weigh the possible outcomes of a decision by assigning probabilities to payoff values and finding expected values.
Use probability to evaluate outcomes of decisions
Higher Mathematics Course — Statistics and Probability<sup>★</sup>

content: Find the expected payoff for a game of chance.
meta: (+) Weigh the possible outcomes of a decision by assigning probabilities to payoff values and finding expected values.
Use probability to evaluate outcomes of decisions
Higher Mathematics Course — Statistics and Probability<sup>★</sup>

content: Fit a linear function for a scatter plot that suggests a linear association.
meta: Represent data on two quantitative variables on a scatter plot, and describe how the variables are related.
Summarize, represent, and interpret data on two categorical and quantitative variables

content: Informally assess the fit of a function by plotting and analyzing residuals.
meta: Represent data on two quantitative variables on a scatter plot, and describe how the variables are related.
Summarize, represent, and interpret data on two categorical and quantitative variables
Higher Mathematics Course — Statistics and Probability<sup>★</sup>

content: Fit a function to the data; use functions fitted to data to solve problems in the context of the data.
meta: Represent data on two quantitative variables on a scatter plot, and describe how the variables are related.
Summarize, represent, and interpret data on two categorical and quantitative variables

content: The dilation of a line segment is longer or shorter in the ratio given by the scale factor.
meta: Verify experimentally the properties of dilations given by a center and a scale factor:
Understand similarity in terms of similarity transformations

content: A dilation takes a line not passing through the center of the dilation to a parallel line, and leaves a line passing through the center unchanged.
meta: Verify experimentally the properties of dilations given by a center and a scale factor:
Understand similarity in terms of similarity transformations

content: Recognize situations in which a quantity grows or decays by a constant percent rate per unit interval relative to another.
meta: Distinguish between situations that can be modeled with linear functions and with exponential functions.
Construct and compare linear, quadratic, and exponential models and solve problems

content: Recognize situations in which one quantity changes at a constant rate per unit interval relative to another.
meta: Distinguish between situations that can be modeled with linear functions and with exponential functions.
Construct and compare linear, quadratic, and exponential models and solve problems

content: Prove that linear functions grow by equal differences over equal intervals, and that exponential functions grow by equal factors over equal intervals.
meta: Distinguish between situations that can be modeled with linear functions and with exponential functions.
Construct and compare linear, quadratic, and exponential models and solve problems

content: Produce an invertible function from a non-invertible function by restricting the domain.
meta: Build new functions from existing functions

content: Read values of an inverse function from a graph or a table, given that the function has an inverse.
meta: Build new functions from existing functions

content: Verify by composition that one function is the inverse of another.
meta: Build new functions from existing functions

content: Solve an equation of the form f(x) = c for a simple function f that has an inverse and write an expression for the inverse.
meta: Build new functions from existing functions

content: Compose functions.
meta: Write a function that describes a relationship between two quantities <sup>★</sup>
Build a function that models a relationship between two quantities

content: Combine standard function types using arithmetic operations.
meta: Write a function that describes a relationship between two quantities <sup>★</sup>
Build a function that models a relationship between two quantities

content: Determine an explicit expression, a recursive process, or steps for calculation from a context.
meta: Write a function that describes a relationship between two quantities <sup>★</sup>
Build a function that models a relationship between two quantities

content: Use the properties of exponents to interpret expressions for exponential functions.
meta: Write a function defined by an expression in different but equivalent forms to reveal and explain different properties of the function.

content: Use the process of factoring and completing the square in a quadratic function to show zeros, extreme values, and symmetry of the graph, and interpret these in terms of a context.
meta: Write a function defined by an expression in different but equivalent forms to reveal and explain different properties of the function.

content: Graph exponential and logarithmic functions, showing intercepts and end behavior, and trigonometric functions, showing period, midline, and amplitude.
meta: Graph functions expressed symbolically and show key features of the graph, by hand in simple cases and using technology for more complicated cases.<sup>★</sup>

content: Graph rational functions, identifying zeros and asymptotes when suitable factorizations are available, and showing end behavior.
meta: Graph functions expressed symbolically and show key features of the graph, by hand in simple cases and using technology for more complicated cases.<sup>★</sup>

content: Graph polynomial functions, identifying zeros when suitable factorizations are available, and showing end behavior.
meta: Graph functions expressed symbolically and show key features of the graph, by hand in simple cases and using technology for more complicated cases.<sup>★</sup>

content: Graph square root, cube root, and piecewise-defined functions, including step functions and absolute value functions.
meta: Graph functions expressed symbolically and show key features of the graph, by hand in simple cases and using technology for more complicated cases.<sup>★</sup>

content: Graph linear and quadratic functions and show intercepts, maxima, and minima.
meta: Graph functions expressed symbolically and show key features of the graph, by hand in simple cases and using technology for more complicated cases.<sup>★</sup>

content: Solve quadratic equations by inspection (e.g., for x² = 49), taking square roots, completing the square, the quadratic formula and factoring, as appropriate to the initial form of the equation. Recognize when the quadratic formula gives complex solutions and write them as a ± bi for real numbers a and b.
meta: Solve quadratic equations in one variable.
Solve equations and inequalities in one variable

content: Use the method of completing the square to transform any quadratic equation in x into an equation of the form (x - p)² = q that has the same solutions. Derive the quadratic formula from this form.
meta: Solve quadratic equations in one variable.
Solve equations and inequalities in one variable

content: Use the properties of exponents to transform expressions for exponential functions.
meta: Choose and produce an equivalent form of an expression to reveal and explain properties of the quantity represented by the expression.<sup>★</sup>
Write expressions in equivalent forms to solve problems

content: Complete the square in a quadratic expression to reveal the maximum or minimum value of the function it defines.
meta: Choose and produce an equivalent form of an expression to reveal and explain properties of the quantity represented by the expression.<sup>★</sup>
Write expressions in equivalent forms to solve problems

content: Factor a quadratic expression to reveal the zeros of the function it defines.
meta: Choose and produce an equivalent form of an expression to reveal and explain properties of the quantity represented by the expression.<sup>★</sup>
Write expressions in equivalent forms to solve problems

content: Interpret complicated expressions by viewing one or more of their parts as a single entity.
meta: Interpret expressions that represent a quantity in terms of its context <sup>★</sup>

content: Interpret parts of an expression, such as terms, factors, and coefficients.
meta: Interpret expressions that represent a quantity in terms of its context <sup>★</sup>

content: Compute the magnitude of a scalar multiple cv using ||cv|| = |c|v. Compute the direction of cv knowing that when |c|v ? 0, the direction of cv is either along v (for c > 0) or against v (for c < 0).
meta: (+) Multiply a vector by a scalar.
Higher Mathematics Course — Number and Quantity

content: Represent scalar multiplication graphically by scaling vectors and possibly reversing their direction; perform scalar multiplication component-wise, e.g., as c(v<sub>x</sub>, v<sub>y</sub>) = (cv<sub>x</sub>, cv<sub>y</sub>).
meta: (+) Multiply a vector by a scalar.
Higher Mathematics Course — Number and Quantity

content: Understand vector subtraction v - w as v + (-w), where -w is the additive inverse of w, with the same magnitude as w and pointing in the opposite direction. Represent vector subtraction graphically by connecting the tips in the appropriate order, and perform vector subtraction component-wise.
meta: Higher Mathematics Course — Number and Quantity

content: Given two vectors in magnitude and direction form, determine the magnitude and direction of their sum.
meta: Higher Mathematics Course — Number and Quantity

content: Add vectors end-to-end, component-wise, and by the parallelogram rule. Understand that the magnitude of a sum of two vectors is typically not the sum of the magnitudes.
meta: Higher Mathematics Course — Number and Quantity
